articles.title: Forms of 'You' - Singular
articles.text:
Forms of 'You' - Singular

This module answers the question: How do I know if the word 'you' is singular?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • English Parts of Speech

Forms of "You" in the Bible

The Bible was first written in the Hebrew and Greek languages. These languages both have a singular form of you and a plural form of you. Therefore we know when each “you” in the Bible should be 'singular' or plural. But even when reading the Bible in a language that does not have distinct singular and plural forms of “you,” the context will often make it clear whether the word “you” is intended to refer to one person, to two people, or to more than two people. If the target language has a dual form of “you” that is used for speaking to only two people, the translator will need to decide from the context when it is appropriate to use this form.

Some languages, like English, have only one word for ‘you’ regardless of how many people are being spoken to. English speakers can refer to one person as ‘you’ or to many people as ‘you.’ Often the context will make it clear as to whether the word ‘you’ refers to one person or more than one. Looking at the other pronouns in the sentence will help you distinguish the number of people who are being spoken to.

Some languages have more than one word for ‘you’ depending on how many people are being spoken to. If they are speaking to one person, they use the ‘singular’ form of ‘you’. If they are speaking to more than one person, they use the ‘plural’ form of ‘you.’ Some languages have a ‘dual’ form for speaking to two people and some have other forms for speaking to three or four people.

Translation Suggestions

Note that for many languages, the decision about what form of the pronoun to use will also affect the form of the verb associated with it, even in cases where the word “you” is not expressed (for example when a command is given).

Examples from the Bible

He said, “I have observed all these things from my youth up.” When Jesus heard this, he said to him, “ You still lack one thing. Sell everything you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.” -Luke 18:21, 22

Note that even though English does not have singular and plural forms of ‘you’, the context indicates that this word ‘you’ here only refers to one person. The man had just told Jesus “ I have observed these things” and Jesus responded with “you”, referring only to that one man.

Then the angel said to him, “Put on your clothes and sandals.” And Peter did so. “Wrap your cloak around you and follow me,” the angel told him. -Acts 12:8

The context makes it clear that the angel is addressing one person, so the singular form of “you” would be used here in languages that make that distinction. The verbs “put on“ and “wrap” would also need the singular form.

To Titus, my true son in our common faith…The reason I left you in Crete was that you might straighten out what was left unfinished and appoint elders in every town, as I directed you …. You must teach what is in accord with sound doctrine.” -Titus 1:2,5; 2:1

Sometimes instruction is addressed to only one person, so the singular form of “you“ would be used. The context will make that clear. This often happens in a letter.

Also watch the video for the computer ( http://youtu.be/cPtjzJ2Advk ) or the tablet/phone ( http://youtu.be/AVITfDEk8nc ).

articles.title: Explicit and Implicit
articles.text:
Explicit and Implicit

This module answers the question: What do the words explicit and implicit mean?

Definition

There are two different forms of communication found in both written and spoken messages. One is called explicit and the other is called implicit . When a speaker, or writer, has a message to give, he has a particular audience in mind as he gives the message. This affects the form of his message and his decision on what information to include or leave out.

  • Information that the speaker states clearly is called explicit information. This is the information that the speaker or writer has decided to include in what he says.
  • Information that the speaker does not state clearly is called implicit information. This is the information that the speaker or writer expects his audience to already know, and so he knows that he does not need to include that information in what he writes.

When a writer writes, he has in mind a certain audience who will read what he writes. The writer has a good idea of what this audience does and does not know about what he is writing about, and so the writer chooses to include the important information that he knows his audience does not know. He chooses to not include the information that his audience already knows.

Translation Suggestions

Although implicit information is not stated in words but is only implied, it is information that the hearer or reader needs to know if he is to understand the meaning of the message. The speaker or writer has succeeded in communicating his message only if the hearer or reader correctly understands what was clearly stated as well as what was implied.

When we translate the Bible, we are making it available to a new audience. This new audience will know some things about what is in the Bible, but often they will not know some of the implicit information that the original writer left out because his original audience already knew it. The new target audience, then, will need to know some of that implicit information in order to understand some parts of the text. So in order for the Bible to communicate its message successfully, the translator needs to include some of the information that the original writer left as implicit for the original audience. If this information can be included in just a few words, then the translator may decide to include this information in the text of the translation. But if it will take more than a few words, it is best to include this information in a footnote. The translator will need to think about his target audience and decide when to include some of this implicit information. Checking the translation with the community is a good way for the translator to find out where he needs to include some implicit information so that they can understand the translation.

articles.title: Making Implicit Information Explicit
articles.text:
Making Implicit Information Explicit

This module answers the question: How do I make implicit information explicit?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Explicit and Implicit

Explanation

When a writer writes a message, he includes the information that his audience needs to know, and leaves out the information that he knows that they already know. When we translate a message, such as the Bible, for a new audience, they may not know some of that information that the original writer did not say. That is the implicit information. Because the author is counting on the audience knowing this implicit information, this information is also part of the message, even though it is not stated. So in the places where the target audience needs to know the implicit information in order to understand the text, and they do not know it, you must put it in the translation, either in the text or in a footnote.

But translators need to be particularly sensitive when thinking about adding such information to the translation that is not stated explicitly in the source text because:

  • Sometimes there will be things that are intentionally unclear in the text. In those cases, the translator should try to keep it unclear also in the translation, if it is possible to keep it unclear in the same way.
  • It is not necessary to include all implicit information for the target audience to understand the text. There is a lot of information that the original audience knew about the things that are in the Bible. Only include the information that the target audience needs to know so that the message is clear, nothing more.

The translator's goal should be to make sure that the reader understands the original meaning of the message. The translation should always have the same meaning as the source text had for its original audience, not more meaning, not less meaning, and not different meaning.

Implicit information may be made explicit in order to make the translation clear if:

  • Only the implicit information that the original audience would have known is made explicit,
  • the added information is necessary so that the target audience will understand the main point of the message,
  • The translation would communicate no meaning or a wrong meaning without the added information,
  • No new information is added that is not part of the original message (do not add something just because you read it in a commentary),
  • the added information does not change the meaning, making it no longer true or accurate,
  • the added information is suitable to the original situation in which the message was given.

As always, you need to ask yourself if your translation is communicating accurately and clearly what the original message was saying.

Examples from the Bible

She ate all that she wanted and had some left over. -Ruth 2:14

Some languages may need to add an object where English (or whatever source language is being used) doesn't have one. Here, the implied object is “roasted grain” or simply “food.” If the target language requires an object for these verbs, you could translate, She ate all the roasted grain that she wanted and had some food left over.

So Yahweh came down to see the city and the tower which the descendants of Adam had built. -Genesis 11:5

The phrase “came down” refers to where he came from. The place he came from was understood by the original readers. But if this sentence is unclear for the target audience, you may name the place to make the information explicit as in: So Yahweh came down from heaven to see the city and the tower which the descendants of Adam had built.

These latter five kings joined together in the valley of Siddim (also called the Salt Sea). -Genesis 14:3

The information that the armies of the five kings were with these five kings was understood by the original readers. But if this information is not understood by the target audience, the information that their armies were with them can be made explicit: “These latter five kings and their armies joined together….”

To Enoch was born Irad. Irad became the father of Mehujael. -Genesis 4:18

It is stated explicitly that Enoch had a child named Irad and that Irad had a child named Mehujael. The implied information is that Irad grew up to be a man and married a woman and through her, had a son. If the verse is confusing without this information for the target audience, you may add as much information as is necessary, such as, “Enoch grew up and married and became the father of a son whom he named Irad. When Irad grew up he became the father of a son whom he named Mehujael.”

Examples from English

  • David asks Susan: “Where is Joe?” David’s question is explicit because it is clearly stated and easily understood by Susan.
  • Susan answers, “At work.” Susan’s response leaves out who she is talking about - this information is implicit. But David understands that information and that her message is, in fact, “Joe is at work.”

articles.title: Hypothetical Situations
articles.text:
Hypothetical Situations

This module answers the question: What are hypothetical situations?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Figures of Speech

Definition

Something that is hypothetical is 'assumed' or 'supposed.' A hypothetical situation is a possible scenario from any point in time: past, present or future. A hypothetical situation in the past did not happen, but could have happened under different circumstances. A hypothetical situation in the present or future may or may not actually happen - the speaker presents it as hypothetical because he does not know or it depends on the actions of others. It could possibly happen or it may never happen. A hypothetical situation might mean asking a “what if” question. It might be a “suppose” or “if only” statement. Hypothetical situations are good teaching tools. Jesus often used them in his teaching.

Translation Suggestions

  • How would your language express a situation that could never happen?
  • How would you communicate a “suppose” scenario that could happen right now?
  • How would your language express a situation that may or may not happen in the future?
  • Does your language have a special way of indicating a hypothetical situation in the past?
  • How does your language express an “if only” or “I wish” scenario which also implies some emotion?

It is important in translation to be able to recognize a hypothetical situation in the text and use appropriate words or phrases. You may need to show the timing of the hypothetical situation (e.g. past, present or future). You may need to clarify that the scenario is only a possibility: that it might be true or not likely to be true; that it could possibly happen or would never happen. Hypothetical situations may or may not imply emotions or reasons. Some hypothetical statements may use expressions such as “what if”, “suppose” or “if only” to help the reader understand the type of hypothetical situation. Perhaps your language uses special wording or specific language structures to communicate each of these things.

Examples from the Bible

1. Consider a hypothetical situation that would never happen :

In Luke chapter 18 verse 25 Jesus was teaching his disciples about how being rich can make it hard to enter God’s kingdom. To emphasize this, he said that it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to submit to God’s rule in their life.

The hypothetical part of this is that a large camel could never squeeze through the eye of a very small sewing needle! Jesus used this hypothetical scenario to emphasize his teaching point.

2. Consider a “suppose” scenario that could possibly happen .

In Matthew chapter 12 verse 11, Jesus was pointing out to the religious leaders that they were not being honest when they judged people for working on the Sabbath day. He told them, “Suppose one of you has a sheep and it falls into a deep hole on the Sabbath day. Certainly, you would work to pull it out of the hole!”

Jesus wasn’t talking about a specific person who did this. Rather, he was talking about a possible situation which could and often did happen. He used the hypothetical story to help listeners understand his own work (God's work).

3. The following is an example of a hypothetical scenario in the past :

In Matthew 11:21, Jesus said that if the people living in the ancient cities of Tyre and Sidon had been able to see the miracles that he – Jesus – performed, they would have repented long ago.

This is a hypothetical situation that we know did not happen. Jesus was making the spiritual teaching point of “what if” these people had seen the miracles? If they had seen the miracles, then, they would have repented.

4. Often a hypothetical situation in the past expresses an emotion, such as regret . For example, consider Exodus 16:3:

“ If only we had died by the hand of Yahweh in the land of Egypt… .”

Here the Israelites are afraid that they will have to suffer and die of hunger in the wilderness, and so they are wishing that they had stayed in Egypt and died there with full stomachs.

Also watch the video for the computer ( http://youtu.be/GfFX1wWjJhA ) or the tablet/phone ( http://youtu.be/jIbY2ikNtHU ).

articles.title: Order of Events
articles.text:
Order of Events

This module answers the question: Is it important to have the order of events correct?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Figures of Speech

Explanation

In the Bible, events are not always told in the order in which they occurred. Sometimes the author wanted to discuss something that happened at an earlier time than the event that he just talked about. Many languages do this by using different tenses or time words such as ‘earlier,’ ‘last year,’ or ‘before that.’ Other languages prefer to state the events in the order that they occurred to avoid confusion. For events that are told in the order in which they occurred, it is also necessary in many languages to mark the order of events with connecting words such as “after these things,” “having done this,” or “then.” It is important to help your readers understand the correct order of events in a natural way when translating into your language.

Translation Suggestions

In order to make the order of events clear in the target language, it may be necessary at times to put some verses or parts of verses in a different order. When you put verses in a different order, you may need to combine the verse numbers so that the numbers can stay in the right order, such as labelling a chunk of two reordered verses as 5-6. You should only put verses in a different order when necessary to avoid confusion or wrong meaning. The translation should always be clear, accurate, and natural.

Pay close attention to time words such as, “yesterday,” “last year,” “before,” “then,” or “next year.” Make sure that you include all of the time words necessary for your audience to understand the order of events. It is also important that your audience understand clearly the order of arguments, such as reasons or causes. Some languages put the reasons or causes for things before the event or the main point of an argument, and other languages put reasons and causes after the main point or event. Use whichever order is natural for your language. It may also be helpful to use words such as, “therefore” or “because.”

Examples from the Bible

Following the Greek wording, the English Standard Version of Luke 10:34 says,

“He (The Samaritan) went to him and bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine“ (ESV).

This could sound like the Samaritan bandaged the wounds and then poured oil and wine on the bandages or that he did all of this at the same time. To make the order of what happened more clear, you might consider rearranging the phrases in this sentence to read,

“The Samaritan went to him, poured oil and wine on his wounds, and put bandages on them.”

Sometimes to emphasize a point or highlight a contrast between two events, the Bible text presents things in a different order than they occurred. The ESV of Luke 8:37-38 says,

37 “…So he (Jesus) got into the boat and returned (to the other side of the lake). 38 The man from whom the demons had gone begged that he might be with him, but Jesus sent him away, saying…”

In verse 37, it sounded like Jesus had already left in the boat, but in the next verse the man is talking to him. We need to understand that the man spoke to Jesus before Jesus left. Luke first talked about the people begging Jesus to leave and Jesus' response to them in verse 37, then he talked about the man begging Jesus to go with him and Jesus' response to the man in verse 38. Luke is showing us the contrast between the two kinds of people. This is a Greek language pattern that is not natural in English because the events are out of order. Some languages will have to make the order of events clear by saying,

“Before Jesus left, the man said to him….”

Other languages may need to switch the order of the verses:

37-38 The man from whom the demons had gone begged that he might be with him, but Jesus sent him away, saying…then he got into the boat and returned (to the other side of the lake)”.

Examples from English

Typically people start each day by doing the same steps. For example,

  • Wake up
  • Get out of bed
  • Get dressed

English prefers telling events in the order that they occur. So for English we would not say, “Every morning I get dressed, wake up, and get out of bed.” The preferred order would be, “Every morning when I wake up, I get out of bed and get dressed.”

Also watch the video for the computer ( http://youtu.be/Fp9qgVoTwss ) or the tablet/phone ( http://youtu.be/AljK2GUdXxc ).

articles.title: Parables
articles.text:
Parables

This module answers the question: What is a parable?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Figures of Speech

Explanation

The kind of communication that we call “parable” includes narrative stories, metaphors, similes, proverbs, and even riddles. The intent of a parable is to convey meaning through a story or word picture. A parable is not an actual account of an event; it is more like an imaginary or hypothetical example (e.g. This could happen). It can be used to explain the kingdom of Heaven by telling a story which the listeners can understand. Because the lesson comes in the form of a story, the listener or reader can feel themselves being a part of it; it is more likely to make an impact on their lives.

Translation Suggestions

Parables or teaching stories are best translated as closely as possible to the way they were originally told. Because the parables are set in the culture of Bible times, there may be things that are not easily understood by a modern audience. Follow the guidelines for translating unknown practices or things. But because these are parables and not real events, some things that are known to the target audience can be substituted for things that are unknown to them, as long as they existed in the time period. Parables are best translated as a situation that can be understood within your own culture. The parable is a teaching story, so it is important that all of the details and parts of the story support the main point of the story. It is important that you understand this main point of the parable before you translate it.

When Jesus told a parable, he did not always intend for his hearers to understand what it meant right away (for example, the parable of the farmer planting seeds). So do not try to explain the story or what Jesus was teaching, but simply translate the parable. Use the form that your language has for communicating that a narrative is an imaginative story (or even a story whose purpose is to teach something) and not an account of a historical event.

Parables seldom (if ever) contain the names of specific individuals (That may be a key for you in identifying what is a parable and what is a narrative account.)

(See: Simile , Metaphor , Hypothetical Situations )

Examples from the Bible

Jesus said to them, “Certainly you will say this proverb to me, 'Doctor, heal yourself. Whatever we heard that you did in Capernaum, do it here in your hometown too.'” -Luke 4:23 ULB
Then he also told them a parable . “Can a blind person guide another blind person? If he did, they would both fall into a pit, would they not? -Luke 6:39 ULB
