articles.title: How to Use the Resources in translationStudio
articles.text:
How to Use the Resources in translationStudio

This module answers the question: How do I use the Resources in translationStudio?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Create and Edit Text
  • Introduction to Resources

Resources in tS

To help translators make the best translation possible, Translation Resources have been created. The Resources include Translation Notes, Important Terms, and Translation Questions.

Translation Notes are cultural, linguistic, and exegetical notes that help to describe and explain the context in which the stories from Open Bible Stories and the Bible was written as well as inform the translator of translation options available to them.

The Important Terms are key terms found in Open Bible Stories and the Bible. It is crucial that they be translated correctly. Each Important Term has a small article written about it as well as cross-references to other places that term is used in Open Bible Stories and the Bible to ensure that it has been translated correctly there, too.

The Translation Questions are available for the translator to check their work. These questions can be asked of anyone checking the translation work. Read the question, answer the question from the information in the translated text, look at the answer. Do both of the answers match? Then the transaltion is clear and accurate.

Once you have consulted the Translation Resources, then you are ready to make the best translation.

Please use the Translation Resources when checking your translation!

articles.title: Backup and Share Your Work
articles.text:
Backup and Share Your Work

This module answers the question: How do I backup and share my work?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Create and Edit Text

Backup & Share

You can share your work for another program, send it to another device, or put it on an SD card. When your work is on a storage card, you can put it on a computer or device that has the translationStudio app.

Note: You can only move or share the changes that have been made on the device you are using to perform this function. In these instructions, “your work” means any changes made on this device.

To share, move, or store your work, complete these steps:

  1. Tap the three dots on the bottom left of the editing window.
  2. Tap Backup on the list.
  3. At the Backup screen, select what you want to do.
  4. Tap Backup to SD Card to move your work onto the SD card inserted into your device. This function will not work if no SD card is inserted into the device.
  5. Tap Send to another app to export your work.
    1. Tap Android Beam to send your work to a nearby device that has translationStudio installed on it. The app will attempt to locate the device.
    2. Tap Bluetooth to send your work to a nearby device. If it continues searching for more than a minute, exit the screen and verify that the devices are paired through Bluetooth.
    3. Tap Drive to send your work to a Google Drive that has been created before. This requires an Internet connection.
    4. Tap Gmail to send your work to an email account. This requires an Internet connection.
    5. Tap Slack to send your work to the Door43 Slack account.
  6. When you are finished, tap outside the Backup Screen to return to the translation screen.

Update translationStudio Projects

This module answers the question: How do I update translationStudio projects?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Install translationStudio on an Android Device

How to Update tS Projects

To update project information on your device, complete the steps below. The translationStudio program is updated each time you open the app.

Note: This process requires an Internet connection.

To update translationStudio projects:

  1. In the Your Translation Projects section, tap the three dots on the left.
  2. In the list of options, tap Update Library .
  3. This process uses the Internet connection. Tap 'Yes' to continue. Tap 'No' to exit.

  5. Tap on a language. Another window opens - choose to download or not.
  6. When all the desired languages are downloaded, tap the back arrow at the top left of the window to return to the Translation Projects section.

articles.title: Publish Content to unfoldingWord
articles.text:
Publish Content to unfoldingWord

This module answers the question: How do I publish content to unfoldingWord?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Backup and Share Your Work

Publishing

When you publish your work there are several steps to the process. The process begins in translationStudio when you select Publish from the 3 dot icon menu. The process continues in Door43 when you submit the Request to Publish form for your updated text.

The Request to Publish form includes several pieces of data such as your contact information, the requested checking level, translation contributors, etc. The person who reviews the request will verify that each contributor provided a legal signature.

Complete the following steps to publish your work:

Step 1: Upload your work

  1. In translationStudio, select the … icon to access the options menu.
  2. Select the Publish icon.
  3. In the tabs at the top of the page:
    1. Select Check Profile . This is where you can see who submitted the work.
    2. Select Review . If there is a green checkmark next to your updated text, select the Next Step button.
    3. Select Upload . This will open an uploading popup.
    4. When the Success popup opens, select OK .

Step 2: Merge your work onto Door43

  1. Open Door43 and navigate to your text.
  2. To continue and integrate your changes, select the red number icon .
  3. Review your changes. You should be able to view every text chunk side by side with the previous version.
  4. Scroll all the way down until you see the buttons: Dismiss , Edit & Apply and Apply .
    1. To cancel the publishing process, select Dismiss .
    2. To make further changes, select Edit & Apply . You can then make your changes and apply them to continue with the Publish process.
    3. To continue without making changes, select Apply .

At this point your work will be accessible on Door43 and may be downloaded and shared. If ready, we strongly encourage that your work be published.

Step 3: Request to Publish

  1. Return to the top of the page. Above the title of your text, click on the Request to Publish link to open the form.
  2. Complete all fields on the form. If you leave a field blank it will delay the approval process.
    1. Provide your name in the Requestor field.
    2. Provide your email address in the Email field. Please respond to any emails regarding this publication request in a timely manner to prevent delays in the approval process.
    3. Indicate the Resource Type from the dropdown box.
    4. Select the translation language from the dropdown box. If your language is not listed, send an email to help@door43.org . Also see Find My Language .
    5. Select the translation source from the Source Text dropdown box.
    6. Type the version of the source you used in the Source Version field.
    7. Select the checking level for your text from the Requested checking level dropdown box.
    8. List all contributors in the Contributors field. If a contributor does not want their name listed, use their pseudonym as indicated in their legal signature.
  3. Select File to upload any signature documents or other files necessary to submit this text.
  4. Select Submit to complete your request for publication. This clears the form and returns a confirmation message.

Questions Regarding the Request to Publish Form and Process

What Happens After Text is Approved?

When the Request to Publish is approved, the text is made available on unfoldingword.org for online viewing, as a downloadable, print-ready PDF, and it appear in the unfoldingWord app.

Can Text Be Changed After Level 3 Checking?

Approved text can always be modified in translationStudio even after all checking levels are completed, HOWEVER if you or another user were to submit a Request to Publish for text that has already completed Level 3 checking, there would be questions regarding the reason for overwriting the previously published and checked materials. The approver will look to see who contributed to the change and may contact the requestor and others involved with the translation of the text in question to ensure the changes are valid.

Must All Contributors Be Named?

Due to copyright laws (and these exist no matter what country you are in and no matter what people tell you about laws in that country), you must list every contributor on the Request to Publish form and provide a legal signature for each person. In certain cases we understand they cannot be named, however you can provide the established pseudonym for that person.

articles.text:
Report a Problem

This module answers the question: How do I report a problem?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • translationStudio

Reporting Problems

Sometimes translationStudio may not work as expected.

At times the program may restart, also called a 'crash'. This is most likely not because of what the translator did. When this happens, the Feedback window will open and a request to type into the space an explanation of what was being done just before the program restarted.

At other times, the translator may want to mention a problem with the program or content. For this, go to the Translating Editing Window and tap on the 3 dots found at the bottom left of the window. Choose Feedback from the list. Use the keyboard to type in an explanation of the problem that you have been experiencing.

Note: The Feedback option is only available when there is an Internet connection.

articles.title: Create a Keyboard in tK
articles.text:
Create a Keyboard in tK

This module answers the question: How do I create a keyboard in tK?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • translationKeyboard

Getting Started

  • Decide on the language you want to make a keyboard for
  • Go to: tk.unfoldingword.org/users/sign_in
  • Sign in using your username and password

Keyboard Search

Search through the keyboards already available to ensure the language has not been created or started. Three possibilities are available:

  • The keyboard has been created already, you are done!
  • If the keyboard has been started and not finished, you can:
    • Wait to see if it is in progress and wait for the completion, or
    • Continue the keyboard and complete it.
  • If the desired keyboard is not available, the following suggestions are:
    • Ask the requestor for more information about the keyboard/language desired specifics; such as the symbols needed for the keyboard
    • Search for existing keyboards using a search engine
    • Create a similar, but different keyboard using the information obtained through research.

Or

  • Find a Unicode or UTF website with the correct symbols.

Then:

Create or Edit a Keyboard in tK

At http://tk.unfoldingword.org/ , select the keyboard that is desired if available, or select the “Create New Keyboard”* button at the top of the web page:

  • A new window titled “Create New Keyboard” will appear.
  • Type the name of the keyboard language in the Keyboard name box
  • Pick the ISO Language Code by typing the first three to five letters of the language desired and pick the appropriate code from the list, this should fill in the ISO Region Code.
  • Keyboard Type: Most keyboards the Android 4 row will work, but the 5 row and IOS are also available.
  • Press “Go”
    • Note: If the Keyboard has already been added, select the appropriate keyboard from the “Languages with Keyboards” list or “Recently Updated Keyboards” list.
    • Note: There are plus “+” and “-“ keys at the end of each row. These keys allow more character keys to be added or deleted from each row.

Edit or Add Symbols to a Keyboard

In the next window, press the “Edit Keyboard” button in the top, right corner of the screen.

In the beginning, these boxes will be blank until they are filled the selected symbol, UTF or Unicode selection.

Input the Symbols of the Desired Language in tK

  • Pick the key to be edited by selecting it with the mouse button
  • Select the Default and Shift characters desired or the corresponding UTF-8 or Unicode string for the character.
  • Press “Save Changes”
  • If additional characters are desired for that key
    • Select the key again and press the “Longpress Character” key once for each additional character desired. You will not be able to enter characters into the long keys until the long key boxes are saved.
    • Go back and enter the desired character or UTF-8 or Unicode string.
  • Press “Save Changes”
  • Note: Unicode U+00xx usually translates to UTF-8 “xx”. For example: Unicode “U+0d38” is equal to UTF-8 “d38”. ADD: If you can find the correct unicode chart or symbol set for the language, you may be able to copy and paste symbols or codes from a Word document, Excel spreadsheet or Adobe PDF file into the keyboard keys in the “Edit” mode.

articles.title: Introduction to the Process Manual
articles.text:
Introduction to the Process Manual

This module answers the question: What is the Process Manual?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Finding Answers

Welcome

The Process Manual is a practical guide to help translation teams know what steps need to be taken from start to finish and how those steps are to be taken. While the Translation Manual is a how-to guide for translation theory and the Checking Manual is a how-to guide for checking theory and the Technology Manual is a how-to guide for using certain technology pieces, the Process Manual seeks to give a step-by-step process the translation team can follow. The Process Manual guides the translation team from initial setup to final publishing of translated and checked content.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Getting Started
  • Selecting a Platform
  • Training Before Translation Begins
  • Training Before Checking Begins
  • Introduction to Publishing
  • Introduction to Distribution

articles.title: Getting Started
articles.text:
Getting Started

This module answers the question: What do I need to have in place before getting started?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Introduction to the Process Manual

How to Get Started

Before getting started, you must be able to:

  • Agree with the Statement of Faith , Translation Guidelines , and the Open License . (Everyone involved in the translation and checking will need to sign a statement that work is being done according to those standards.)
  • Read with fluency the source language in which the text and translation helps are available.
  • Gain access to the source text and translation helps either in print form, or online at https://door43.org , or through translationStudio - our mobile app platform (see https://unfoldingword.org/translationstudio/ ).
  • Have access to an internet-connected computer or tablet where the translation can be uploaded and audio (if desired) can be recorded. See “ Suggested Hardware ”.

You should be able to:

  • Know where to get answers to your questions. See “ Get answers to my questions ”.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Selecting a Platform

articles.title: Setting Up A Translation Team
articles.text:
Setting Up A Translation Team

This module answers the question: How can I set up a translation team?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • The Translation Process
  • Getting Started

Translation Teams and the Definition of a Good Translation

There are many important questions that must be considered when setting up a translation and checking team. Perhaps the most important thing to keep in mind is that the goal is a good translation which has four basic characteristics:

  • Clear - Clear translations can only be produced by including native-speakers of the target language, preferably many of them, as translators and checkers
  • Natural - Natural translations can only be produced by including native-speakers of the target language, preferably many of them, as translators and checkers
  • Accurate - Accurate translations can only be produced by people who understand well the language of the source text and notes and preferably the original text, too
  • Church-Approved - Church-Approved translations are most easily produced by including in the translation and checking process as many church networks who speak the target language as possible

Choosing a Team

As you begin selecting a translation and checking team, there are many different types of people and roles that are needed. There are also specific qualifications that are needed for each team.

  • Choosing a Translation Team - Describes many of the roles that are needed
  • Translator Qualifications - Describes some of the skills needed by the translators

Translation Decisions

There are many decisions the translation team will have to make, many of them right at the beginning of the project. Included are the following:

  • Choosing a Source Text - Choosing a good source text is very important
    • Copyrights, Licensing, and Source Texts - Copyright issues must be considered when choosing a source text
    • Source Texts and Version Numbers - Translating from the latest version of a source text is best
  • Alphabet/Orthography - Many languages have alphabet decisions that need to be made
  • Decisions for Writing Your Language - Writing style, punctuation, translating names, spelling, and other decisions have to be made
  • What to Start Translating - Choosing what to translate first is another decision to be made

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Choosing a Translation Team
  • Translator Qualifications
  • Choosing a Source Text
  • Alphabet/Orthography
  • Decisions for Writing Your Language
  • What to Start Translating

articles.title: Selecting a Platform
articles.text:
Selecting a Platform

This module answers the question: How do I choose a translation platform?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Getting Started

Choosing a Translation Platform

Now you need to select a translation and checking platform. This is where the translation and checking teams will do their work. There are four options:

  • Online in a web browser - For those with consistent internet, they can work straight on door43. Click here to set up door43 for translation.
  • Offline on a mobile device - For those with access to an Android tablet or mobile device, they can work offline in our translation app called translationStudio. Click here to set up translationStudio.
  • Offline in a word processor - For those who would like to work in a word processor, they download the files needed to do that. Click here to set up word processor.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Setting up Door43
  • Setting Up translationStudio
  • Setting Up a Word Processor
  • Training Before Translation Begins

articles.title: Setting up Door43
articles.text:
Setting up Door43

Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Selecting a Platform

Getting Started with Door43

To get started on door43, please follow the following steps:

Get Started

And pray for us, too, that God may open a door for our message,
so that we may proclaim the mystery of Christ, for which I am in chains.
- Colossians 4:3 (NIV)

Now that you're ready to translate the Bible, it's time to “open the door” God has provided with the Door43 application. It is surprisingly easy to use, but if you have questions or just want to talk about the app, you can turn to the Door43 user community.

Register as a New User

Go to the Register as a New User page and sign up for an account so you can edit pages.

Please note: You will need to agree to abide by the Statement of Faith , Translation Guidelines , and the Open License

Join the Door43 Community

The Door43 community uses Slack to communicate. When you join our slack channels you can learn about the benefits and challenges of this application and share your ideas with the developers as well as other translators. Slack works well in a Browser or you may download a native client for it as well.

Learn How to Translate, Check, Publish, and Use Our Tools

To learn how to translate, check, publish, and use our tools, check out translationAcademy .

Set up Open Bible Stories

Navigate to your language. If you don't know your IETF language tag, you may search for your language on home page under the Door43 logo. If Open Bible Stories does not appear on your language, then set up Open Bible Stories for your language and begin translating.

If you would like to translate the Bible, please ask the Helpdesk for help (see below).

Further questions

If you have questions, you can post them on the Helpdesk channel in Slack (see above) or email help@door43.org.

Suggestion: When you want to follow a link, right-click on the link and select "Open in new window" from the right-click menu.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Translating in Door43

articles.title: Setting Up translationStudio
articles.text:
Setting Up translationStudio

This module answers the question: How do I set up translationStudio?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Selecting a Platform

Set up the app

  1. First you will need to install translationStudio on an Android device. (See also https://unfoldingword.org/translationstudio/ ))
  2. First time use of translationStudio will require an agreement to the Statement of Faith , the Translation Guidelines , and the Open License .

Set up the source language

  1. Select Source & Target Languages . Go here if you cannot find your language.

For more information on how to use translationStudio see the Technology Manual section on translationStudio .

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • How to Translate in translationStudio

articles.title: Setting Up a Word Processor
articles.text:
Setting Up a Word Processor

This module answers the question: How do I set up a Word Processor?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Selecting a Platform

Obtaining the Source Text for Open Bible Stories

  1. Go to Get Open Bible Stories Word Template
  2. Select your source language (the language from which you will translate) and click “Save”. (Note: If you click the “Add all images in the file”, the download size will increase greatly.) The template will download as a docx file.
  3. Open this template in your word processor of choice.

Obtaining Translation Helps for Open Bible Stories

  • The download for Open Bible Stories translation helps is not currently automated. Please contact Helpdesk for assistance

Obtaining the Source Text & Helps for the Bible

  • This process is not presently automated. Please contact the Helpdesk for further assistance.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Translating in a Word Processor

articles.title: Training Before Translation Begins
articles.text:
Training Before Translation Begins

This module answers the question: What should I know about translation before I start?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • The Translation Process
  • Why We Translate the Bible

What to Know Before Translation

It is recommended that you consult the Translation Manual frequently as you translate this content. Before you start translating, we recommend that you start working your way through the Translation Manual at least until you know the difference between a literal translation and a meaning-based translation. Much of the rest of the Translation Manual can be used as a “just-in-time” learning resource.

Some important subjects that must be learned before starting a translation project:

  • The Qualities of a Good Translation - The definition of a good translation
  • The Translation Process - How a good translation is made
    • Form and Meaning - The difference between form and meaning
    • Meaning-Based Translations - How to make a meaning-based translation

Some other important topics as you get started include:

  • What to Start Translating - Suggestions for where to start translating
  • Make a First Draft - How to make a first draft
  • Help with Translating - Using translation helps

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Choosing a Translation Team
  • Choosing a Source Text
  • Alphabet/Orthography
  • Decisions for Writing Your Language
  • What to Start Translating

articles.title: Translating in Door43
articles.text:
Translating in Door43

This module answers the question: How can I translate in Door43?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Training Before Translation Begins
  • Setting up Door43

Using Translation Helps

  1. Once the source text is setup on Door43, then you are ready to start translating.
    • It is strongly recommended that you consult the translation notes and key terms while doing your translation
  2. For the best way to use translation notes in Door43, please read Use the Translation Notes on Door43

Editing a page

  1. Login to Door43
  2. Navigate to the page you want to edit.
  3. Click on the pencil icon on the right side of the page.
  4. Change whatever is needed.
  5. Be sure to save your work (see below)

Saving My Work

  1. Before you close the edit page, you need to save your work. (If you close the tab or browser or navigate to another page before saving your work, the edits you made will be lost.)
  2. Click the “Save” button. A revision of that page will be saved.

Sharing Your Work

Sharing your work is easy on Door43.

  • Online: Anybody can navigate to the pages you have worked on and see your work.
  • Download: You may also download each page by clicking on one of the three icons at the bottom right part of the page. Downloads are available in .txt, .html, and .odt formats. These downloads can be shared with others offline.

After Translating on Door43

  • Once your translation is complete, you should proceed to Checking

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Training Before Checking Begins
  • How to Check

articles.text:

articles.title: Translating in a Word Processor
articles.text:
Translating in a Word Processor

This module answers the question: How can I translate in a Word Processor?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Training Before Translation Begins
  • Setting Up a Word Processor

Using Translation Helps

  1. Once the source text is setup on your word processor, then you are ready to start translating.
    • It is strongly recommended that you consult the translation notes and key terms while doing your translation
  2. The best way to use the translation notes and key terms is to have that file opened in another window so that they can be quickly and easily referenced while the translation is ongoing.

Changing a page

  • It is recommended that you keep a copy of the source text so that the translation can be compared against the original. This can be done in one of two ways:
    • Put the translation above (or below) the source language but not deleting the source text. (Note: The source text will have to be deleted before uploading.)
    • Make an extra copy of the source text, then delete the source text from the one copy after the translation has been made. When reference to the source text needs to be made, the other copy with the source text can be referenced.

Saving My Work

  • Be sure you save your work frequently to avoid losing your work.

Sharing Your Work

  • These files can be printed, emailed, or otherwise shared so others can be involved in the translation and checking process.

After Translating in a Word Processor

  1. We strongly recommend that your translation be checked .
  2. Once the checking is complete (to any level), you may upload your work.
    1. This feature is presently automated for Open Bible Stories. Please follow the instructions on the Open Bible Stories Upload page.
    2. Please contact the Helpdesk for help with uploading other projects.
  3. Once uploaded, you will need to merge your work into Door43.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Merging an Upload Into Door43
  • Training Before Checking Begins
  • How to Check

articles.title: Merging an Upload Into Door43
articles.text:
Merging an Upload Into Door43

This module answers the question: How can I merge my uploaded content into Door43?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Training Before Translation Begins

Uploading Content Onto Door43

Content can be uploaded from:

  • Word Processor - click here to learn how to Upload Your Work
    • Note: Content uploaded using the above process will automatically merge onto Door43.
  • translationStudio - click here to learn how to Upload Your Work
    • Note: If there is no content for a given resource in given language, then the uploaded content will automatically be merged onto Door43. If there is any conflict, the content must be manually merged.

Merging Uploaded Work Onto Door43

To merge content uploaded by translationStudio:

  1. Login to Door43.
  2. Go to the page needing to be merged.
  3. On the right-hand side above the icon of the “Edit” pencil will appear an icon of two lines merging into one arrow which is labeled “Apply Updates”. Click on “Apply Updates”.
  4. Then you may go through and “Dismiss” or “Apply” changes on Door43. If you choose “Apply” it will overwrite what was on Door43 with what was uploaded, “Dismiss” discards what was uploaded and keeps what was on Door43.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Training Before Checking Begins
  • Introduction to Publishing

articles.title: Training Before Checking Begins
articles.text:
Training Before Checking Begins

This module answers the question: What should I know about checking before I begin?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Training Before Translation Begins

Before Checking

It is recommended that you consult the Checking Manual frequently as you check this content. Before you start checking, we recommend that you start working your way through the Checking Manual until you understand what is required at each level. As you work through the checking process, you will need to consult the Checking Manual frequently.

Note: Content will not be published to the unfoldingWord website or mobile app until it has attained at least checking level 1.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Introduction to the Checking Manual
  • The Goal of Checking
  • How to Check

articles.title: How to Check
articles.text:
How to Check

This module answers the question: How do I check a translation?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Training Before Checking Begins

Purpose of Checking Levels

The purpose the checking levels is primarily to help ensure that the translation has been made in accordance with the Statement of Faith and the Translation Guidelines . Another purpose for the checking levels is to increase the input and ownership of the translation among the community that will be using it.

Checking Level 1

Checking Level 1 is done primarily by the translation team, with some input from the language community.

Please follow the Steps for checking under Level One to complete a Level 1 check.

After completing the Level 1 Check, you are encouraged to publish your translation and continue on to Checking Level 2 (see below).

Checking Level 2

Checking Level 2 is done to verify that representative groups from the local language community agree that the translation is a good one. It is done with a language community check and a church leader check .

After completing the Level 2 Check, you are encouraged to publish your translation and continue on to Checking Level 3 (see below), if you so desire.

Checking Level 3

Checking Level 3 has two possible tracks: track one requires church networks to approve the translation and track two requires one church network and one trained translation consultant. Be sure you work through the Level 3 Checking Questions while you complete this checking level.

After completing the Level 3 Check, you are encouraged to publish your translation. This is the highest checking level.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Introduction to Publishing

articles.title: Introduction to Publishing
articles.text:
Introduction to Publishing

This module answers the question: What is publishing?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Training Before Checking Begins

Publishing Overview

There are two translation platforms that we use - translationStudio and Door43. Once translations have been completed, we encourage these translations to be checked. Once a translation has been checked to at least Level 1, it becomes eligible to be published. Published content is placed on a platform where it remains static. While the content on Door43 can change frequently, the published content is static and assurance of quality remains high.

When content is published, a copy of what is found on Door43 is published to the unfoldingWord website in several formats:

  • To be viewed online
  • In a print-ready PDF for Print-on-Demand
  • On the free unfoldingWord mobile app for offline consumption

Publishable Content

Presently, there are two text resources that can be published using the unfoldingWord publishing engine:

  • Open Bible Stories
  • the Bible

Capacity is being built to be able to handle multimedia formats as well:

  • Audio Open Bible Stories
  • Video Open Bible Stories
  • Audio Bible

Published Content

Published content can be found at https://unfoldingword.org/stories/ and on the unfoldingWord mobile app .

In Door43, a brief statement will appear in resources that may be eligible for publishing which states the status of publishing in that namespace. For instance, at the time of writing the Open Bible Stories in English says “This resource is published on unfoldingWord as checking level 3 and version 4. See it at https://unfoldingword.org/stories .”

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Publishing Prerequisites
  • How to Publish

articles.title: Publishing Prerequisites
articles.text:
Publishing Prerequisites

This module answers the question: What must be done before publishing?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Introduction to Publishing

Before Publishing

Before a resource can be published, the following prerequisites must all be met:

  • Whole Resource - The whole resource must be translated and checked, in other words, parts of resources (e.g. half of the Open Bible Stories, only a few chapters of a book of the Bible) cannot be published.
  • At Least Level 1 - A translation must have reached at least Checking Level 1
  • On Door43 - Door43 must have the version that will be published (if translation or checking was done in translationStudio, you may need to merge your work into Door43).
  • Signatures - Everyone involved in the translation and checking must have signed the Statement of Faith , the Translation Guidelines , and the Open License . This can be done in a number of ways:
    • Everyone create a Door43 account
    • Everyone sign a guidelines and license form

When all these are completed, you are ready to start the Publishing Engine .

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • How to Publish

articles.title: How to Publish
articles.text:
How to Publish

This module answers the question: How do I publish my content?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Introduction to Publishing
  • Publishing Prerequisites

Starting the Publishing Process

Before you start the Publishing Process, please be sure that you have met all the Publishing Prerequisites .

To start the publishing process, someone from the team will need fill out the Request to Publish Form . A few things to note about this form:

  • An email address is required - During the publishing process, the requester will be emailed if there are any problems, and also at the end of the process, requesting a final check be made.
  • Documentation of Contributors is required - To document who was involved, each Checking Level requires that all contributors sign the Statement of Faith , the Translation Guidelines , and the Open License . This documentation is required to start the publishing process. You can download signature forms .
    • Note: To help protect the identity of those who might desire it, pseudonyms/usernames will be cited (if provided) rather than real names in the list of contributors.
  • A “pre-flight” check - Immediately after submitting the Request to Publish form, a computerized check will take place. This check ensures that everything has been translated and that content appears in the correct web pages in Door43. It also does a statistical check which compares the standard deviation from the source language to the target language. Abnormally high or low deviations are flagged and all results of the “pre-flight” check are processed and returned to the requester within a minute or so. If any changes need to be made, they should be made before proceeding.

During the Publishing Process

After the Request to Publish form has been submitted, the following will happen:

  • A documentation check - someone from the unfoldingWord team will check to make sure all the documentation is in place and that the procedures followed during the checking process correspond to the guidelines laid out in the Checking Levels .

If any of the documentation is not correct, the requester will be emailed and the publishing process will stop until the problem is resolved and a “Request to Continue Publishing” form is filled out and submitted.

Finishing the Publishing Process

When the publishing process is complete, the content will be published to the unfoldingWord catalogue which makes it available on the unfoldingWord website as a print-ready PDF and viewable online. It will also be published to the unfoldingWord mobile app . (In order for this newly published content to appear on your unfoldingWord app, you may need to download the latest content from the web.)

The requester will be emailed and informed that the publishing process has been completed and they will be requested to look over the published content to ensure that everything “looks right.”

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • Introduction to Distribution

articles.title: Introduction to Distribution
articles.text:
Introduction to Distribution

This module answers the question: How can I distribute content?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Introduction to Publishing

Distribution Overview

Content is worthless unless it is disseminated and used. One advantage of using the Door43/unfoldingWord translation and publishing platform is that it provides multiple, simple ways of distributing both published and unpublished content.

Open License

The biggest factor that encourages distribution of content is the Open License that is used with all content on Door43 and unfoldingWord. This license gives everybody the freedom they need to:

  • Share — copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format
  • Adapt — remix, transform, and build upon the material for any purpose, even commercially.

Under the terms of the license.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • How to Share Unpublished Content
  • How to Share Published Content

articles.title: How to Share Unpublished Content
articles.text:
How to Share Unpublished Content

This module answers the question: How can I share unpublished content?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Introduction to Distribution

Sharing Unpublished Content from translationStudio

Sharing unpublished content that is contained on translationStudio is easy. Click here to see how.

Sharing Unpublished Content from Door43

If someone has access to the internet, simply send them the link and they will be able to access the content online.

To share the content offline,

  • Log in to Door43
  • Go to the page you want to share
  • On the right-hand side, click on the icon of a page with birds on it for a .odt file, or click on the icon underneath that for a .pdf download.
  • These files can be merged to create a resource and shared as desired.

In addition to this,

  • At the bottom right of each page are three export buttons:
    • TXT - exports the page as a .txt file
    • HTM - exports the page as a .html file
    • ODT - exports the page as a .odt file
  • These files can be merged to create a resource and shared as desired.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • How to Share Published Content

articles.title: How to Share Published Content
articles.text:
How to Share Published Content

This module answers the question: How can I share published content?
Before you start this module have you learned about:

  • Introduction to Distribution

Sharing Published Content Online

All published content can be found online at https://unfoldingword.org .

  • Open Bible Stories can be found at https://unfoldingword.org/stories/
  • The Bible can be found at https://bible.unfoldingword.org/

Sharing Printed Published Content

Print-ready PDFs of published content can be found on the unfoldingWord website . These PDFs can be printed on traditional or print-on-demand printing presses.

These files can also be shared via email, bluetooth, sD card, etc.

Sharing Published Content with the unfoldingWord Mobile App

Installing the unfoldingWord App provides access to all published content contained in the unfoldingWord catalogue.

Next we recommend you learn about:

  • How to Share Unpublished Content
